Award.AwardTitle: CSNYC Knowledge Forum: Launching Research and Evaluation for Computer Science Education, for Every School and Every Student in New York City

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support a workshop to bring together prominent researchers, practitioners, and funders of Computer Science (CS) Education to define the initial agenda for the research and evaluation to accompany the implementation of computer science in every school in New York City (CSNYC). With a 10-year commitment to provide computer science to every student in every school in NYC, New York is at the forefront of a national movement to increase participation in CS education at the K-12 level. Throughout the workshop, CSNYC representatives will be documenting conversations, encouraging groups to describe priorities, and looking for opportunities to not only assess the work in NYC, but also to inform the larger national K-12 CS movement.

The workshop's outcomes focus on evaluation of the expansion of CS Education in NYC and the research that will accompany the CS Education implementation. Using results from this workshop CSNYC will build consensus around key education issues such as teacher training, student outcomes, and curricular implementations. With regards to education research, CSNYC is: identifying and prioritizing topics for research; constructing a roadmap for longitudinal outcomes and necessary data collections; and defining ways in which CSNYC can support the research community in pursuing the research agenda over the course of the expansion of CS Education in NYC. Also, the outcomes of this workshop will help inform initiatives to expand computer science across the country.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computer science (CS) education is rapidly expanding in the United States. Grassroots efforts in cities such as Chicago and New York, as well as states such as Arkansas, were echoed in a national call to action to provide “Computer Science for All” in K-12 schools and districts. CSNYC has undertaken a 10-year partnership with the NYC Mayor’s Office and NYC Department of Education to provide CS to every student in every school in NYC, putting the city at the forefront of a national movement to increase participation in CS education at the K-12 level.

NYC’s CS4All initiative (www.cs4all.nyc) also presents a unique opportunity to advance a larger CS education research agenda. To that end, CSNYC engaged many of the most prominent researchers, practitioners, and funders of CS education to define an initial agenda for the research and evaluation to accompany the implementation of CS in every school in NYC. CSNYC offered a one-day workshop of a strategically selected group of approximately 60 attendees. The agenda for this meeting included short talks by key representatives from CS education and small-group breakout sessions focused on specific issues related to researching and evaluating the expansion of CS education to all students. Throughout the day, CSNYC representatives documented conversations, encouraged groups to describe priorities, solicited feedback and looked for opportunities not only to assess the work in NYC, but also to inform the larger national movement.

The CSNYC Knowledge Forum had the goal of convening a national meeting of CS education researchers and evaluators with a focus on the evaluation of CS education, using NYC’s CS4All initiative as a case study, in order to: (1) build consensus around priority issues such as teacher training, student outcomes, and curricular implementations; (2) prioritize topics for research in CS education; (3) clarify key considerations for internal evaluations for continuous program improvement; and (4) define ways in which CSNYC can support the research community in pursuing the research agenda over the course of the CS4All initiative.

CSNYC hosted a meeting on April 14, 2016 at AppNexus in New York City. Before the meeting 69 attendees registered, including four CSNYC staff members. The meeting agenda is available on the CSNYC web page at https://csnyc.org/our-work/csnyc-programs/knowledge-forum-2016. CSNYC convened a follow-up group of the organization’s Education Advisory Council in June 2016 in order to discuss outcomes from the Knowledge Forum event and make programmatic recommendations for the NYC CS4All evaluation.

Participants were asked to brainstorm key challenges in CS education and create categories in their working groups. Participants placed the categories they created on a plot of priority vs. possible - comparing how important a topic was with how easy the work was to accomplish.  In the products, we link to a web page with an interactive visualization of this plot. The categories had the following average priorities from the participants (all numbers are out of a maximum 8): Implementation (4.1), Equity (5.3), Sustainability & Scale (4.6), Research and Evaluation (3.7), Community (1.3), Teacher Development (4.2), and Curriculum (2.5).  The categories had the average possibility score where a higher possibility is easier to accomplish (all numbers are out of a maximum 8): Implementation (4.9), Equity(4.6), Sustainability & Scale (4.5), Research and Evaluation (6.0), Community (6.8), Teacher Development (5.0) and Curriculum (5.1).

CSNYC also submitted, was approved for, and conducted a special session at the ACM Technical Symposium for Computer Science Education (SIGCSE) in March 2017. Additionally, a visualization of the brainstorm activities is available at https://csnyc.github.io/priority-probability/. Overall, the event met the goals for the workshop, and post-event surveys (N=32) indicate the event was highly informative for the community (75% of responses indicated sessions were informative or very informative on a five-point scale).


Last Modified: 05/19/2017
Modified by: Leigh A Delyser

Grassroots efforts in cities such as Chicago and New York, as well as states such as Arkansas, were echoed in a national call to action to provide "Computer Science for All" in K-12 schools and districts. CSNYC has undertaken a 10-year partnership with the NYC Mayor?s Office and NYC Department of Education to provide CS to every student in every school in NYC, putting the city at the forefront of a national movement to increase participation in CS education at the K-12 level. NYC?s CS4All initiative (www.cs4all.nyc) also presents a unique opportunity to advance a larger CS education research agenda.
